repnme.cdata!: India - Uttar Pradesh Social Forestry Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Forestry Project for Uttar
            Pradesh, India achieved extraordinary success with its
            component for plantation of trees by farmers on their
            private land. The community plantation component, which
            aimed to develop self-help woodlots, did not succeed due to
            a variety of economic and sociological reasons. Overall, the
            project started promptly and progressed on a timely basis.
            It closed on schedule in December 1984 and the credit amount
            was fully disbursed. There were revisions in the project
            design, determined during the mid-term review, including the
            dropping of the fuel-efficient stove component.
            Sustainability is likely for Uttar Pradesh's capability
            to handle its plantation programs and even teach others.
            However, the Forest Department has not established a firm
            capacity for certain qualitative aspects, including
            institutional weaknesses resulting in poor delivery of
            advice to farmers; distribution and marketing aspects of
            tree production; and subsistence fuel needs of the poor and
            urban populations. The Bank performed well. Supervisions
            occurred fairly regularly, and a useful exchange of view
            between mission members and forestry officials often
            occurred. IDA showed flexibility during project
            implementation. There were five lessons learned: (i) to the
            extent that wood production can be handled economically on
            private lands, Forest Departments should turn over that
            responsibility; (ii) Forest Departments have begun to
            experiment with new plantation approaches, a key one being
            tree tenure schemes whereby poor farmers and landless
            persons lease public land at nominal fees and take the
            benefits of the trees they grow there; (iii) social forestry
            should look toward both the supply and demand sides; (iv)
            the social forestry experience has indicated that some
            functions can be handled better by the private sector or
            other organizations; and (v) the project was well
            conceptualized and the overwhelming success of farm forestry
            could not be anticipated.

repnme.cdata!: India - Uttar Pradesh Social Forestry Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed project would expand and
            intensify the social forestry program in Uttar Pradesh. The
            program aims at large-scale tree plantation along roads,
            rails and canals, on village common lands unsuitable for
            cropping, and on degraded forest reserves in need of
            rehabilitation. The trees would provide a much-needed source
            of energy to the villages, raw materials to cottage
            industries, and greater stability to the environment. The
            ultimate objective would be to have the villagers establish
            as soon as possible their own village forests, using
            voluntary labor, with the assistance of state-wide forest
            extension services, for distribution of fuelwood and other
            products to village communities. About 48,600 ha of public
            and village lands would be planted under the project, 45,600
            ha of which would be carried out by the Uttar Pradesh Social
            Forestry Directorate with varying degrees of community participation.
